Author: Aternus#9711
Content: If you request a source from a domain other than yours you need to make sure that source have this header in the appropriate state

Content: So, basically, you want someone to reinvent google drive?

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Kinda

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: But simpler than that though, since it should run on a LAN

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Not to mention it is perfectly free (except some marginal electricity costs) and gives much better speeds, doesn't use your internet connection, and uses your own storage, so you don't need to read the damned privacy policy

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: Really?  I get something like 90MB/sec transfers with google drive

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: i can‚Äôt imagine much faster than saturating my gigabit internet connection

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: the network inside my house is also only gigabit too.

Author: nil4k#5220
Content: also, my fileservers at home end up costing me about $150/mo in electricity because I live in a really expensive location where electricity costs a lot.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Then you have a good internet connection

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: You see, unlike you, I don't have access to a gigabit internet connection. Just 75Mbps

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: And because of certain issues I can't get more than ~5MBps speeds with Google drive

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Not to mention Google drive only gives you limited free storage

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Also, if you use a laptop as a file server you won't consume nearly as much electricity

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Only about as much as a fan on full speed

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: And most people in the world _don't_ have a gigabit connection

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: And last but not the least, I don't like putting my data on _their_ servers because I'm paranoid.

                    force_default=False,
                    force_lower=False,
                    use_ssl=False,
                    base_url=None)``

Content: BTW this 49 isn't the highest score achieved during training - in that the snakes could score well above 100, but the training happens in different threads and is not rendered. Which means that the trained AI can consistently get very good scores, and not just once in a while.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Do what you actually like doing most

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: I've tried a lot of different things, and chances are I'll finally end up doing a physics degree, even though I do like CS and electronics too

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: I totally agree with Lord of Galaxy, it doesn't matter what you choose as long as you have passion towards it and like doing it every day.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content:
Of course, if you like a lot of different things it can be hard to choose. In that case, I would choose with some deep consideration - do you think you will be able to give up on any one the subjects you like? If yes, pick whichever you cannot give up. Otherwise, pick the subject that is hardest to study without going to a college (say, Biology), not one which is easy to study with resources on the internet (like computer science).
Another thing to consider is which one is easiest for you? If getting admission to a course in one subject is much easier than another course, despite being equally renowned, then pick that. If you find some subject easier than another's consider picking that over the other

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Of course, what opportunities are available to you matter too

Author: Oops365#7416
Content: @juansf111 it doesn't look like you've specified a table in your query, and I believe your UPDATE needs  WHERE

Author: Aternus#9711
Content:
@juansf111 you should look into writing code with Discord (it uses Markdown).

## SQL UPDATE Statement

The `UPDATE` statement is used to update existing records in a table.

```sql
UPDATE table_name
SET column1 = value1, column2 = value2, ...
WHERE some_column = some_value;
```

(!): The `WHERE` clause specifies which record or records should be updated.
       If you omit the `WHERE` clause, __ALL RECORDS__ will be updated!

```py
db.execute("<query>", {'clientIP':clientIP, 'offset':offset})
```

Content: So if it‚Äôs taken me a year on and off (family and job allowing) to do the psets I should spend about 2 months on the project?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: the average student spends between 10-14 hours on a pset.  So their final project might be twice that.   How much time you spend on your final project is up to you. If you're satisfied that you've done a project that shows what you've learned in the class, then that's fine.  It's graded on the honor system.   If you submit your 2 minute video that demonstrates your project, then you've passed.  If you're satisfied, we are too.

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: @H311 YE4H You need to disable cache in the framework you're using to serve the files

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: Also, using `on` properties in HTML is a not the best solution

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: It make your Markup perform Behavior

Author: Aternus#9711
Content: Instead you should be using the DOM API to query the DOM for these elements (using a class or and ID) and then attaching an event listener for the `change` event

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @starrfighter certificates are issued monthly (at the beginning of the month), so yes, in order to get one in December (ie, next week), you have to finish by the end of Nov.  If you finish in December, then your certificate will be issued in January.  If you finish in Jan, in Feb, etc.

Author: starrfighter#1183
Content:
I worked a lot in GUIs a decade ago interfaced with databases, but it was for in office.   This is why I am GUI python, Tkinter got me interested... .. like VB.NET + MSSQL was a beautiful thing.  I almost can't believe it is declining in use.  You do your gui like old What you see is what you get web editors, It writes a ridiculous amounts of code to make the GUI and then gee you just have to double click a button on the GUI and write the action function, unlike tkinter and other packages which i like but, all the same python makes a window with little coding effort like VB.NET which if you look at the code its only windows and an absurd amount of code that is auto-generated for you.  
Then within that you get to write your simple function.  So, @curiouskiwi...

Author: starrfighter#1183
Content: I felt the last few lectures and  additional material from CS50 were too abrupt.  All of a sudden i was learning or relearning 4 maybe 5 programming syntax and scripts.  I should mention I am horrible at css... I am no artist.  BUT  there is CS50 web, and I am not blind to the fact that web is WEB.  I have to be able.  Would taking CS50 Web be a natural progression, or does it go over too many fundamentals again for too many weeks before hitting the material I need to build from CS50?

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: If you're not a fan of CSS perhaps you shouldn't bother with web development anyways, there are so many other fields that would interest you more

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: However, if all you need is an introduction (since you mention you want to be able), then CS50 Web does that for you. Just skip through whatever you already know

Author: starrfighter#1183
Content: Thanks.   I'm just a bad artist, so if someone else is doing it, great, but I still need to read and adjust.  Also, web is where it is at, I like python, but I just need a lot more JS than what CS50 basic gives you, and SQL I used to be a master but need a reminder on... alot.  Took  a lot of time off.  As long as CS50 Web fills in my gaps, I would like to stick with HarvardX.  They do a reasonably good job compared to some other things I've seen.  But if that is not the right path, I'd like to be discouraged if it's... too repetitive.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Well... You can get away quite easily if you know just basic JS, which you can learn in a day easily.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: So unless you plan on actually going into web development maybe you should consider learning something else

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: You don't _need_ to be an expert at everything

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: As for SQL, that's more backend anyways so you might do well to get a refresher on that

Author: Maarten#1004
Content: @starrfighter if you're interested in the GUI/Python combination, Qt might be worth checking out as well.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Nah, tk is nice

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Nothing wrong in checking other stuff ofc

Author: ArcticWolfe#9894
Content: Does anybody know how I can test POST requests in the CS50 IDE? I'm going to implement form validation that should prevent the user from sending invalid POST requests, but I'm sure there are ways an adversary could send a POST request to my website anyway, and I want to implement some server-side security for that - but I also need to test it. Any suggestions are appreciated! üòÉ

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Use the same form without the validation maybe

Author: Maarten#1004
Content: @ArcticWolfe You could try out fiddler for that: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28326215/how-to-modify-a-request-in-fiddler

Author: Maarten#1004
Content: Depending on what you're using that will probably work. Some frameworks have protection built-in against manipulated requests. If you're using one of those, you'll need to disable that like Lord of Galaxy suggested.

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Ofc you can sit and manually make up POST requests and send them to the localhost using anything like say Python

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: On the required port ofc

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: Lastly, if being hit by attackers won't potentially damage you in any way, just make the website go live and have some people attack it. If your server side validation works then no one will get past it

Author: Lord of Galaxy#9211
Content: And if it doesn't work... No harm done anyways

Content: `to` and `from` are integer columns, yes Ms. Anderson.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: when you run it manually?  no

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `SELECT * FROM mail WHERE to = 1 OR from = 1;`

Author: WhipStreak23#6131
Content: semicolon isn't working...

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: what do you mean?  are you using sqlite3?

Content: `SELECT * FROM mail WHERE to = 1 OR from = 1` Is not working

Author: WhipStreak23#6131
Content: This.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I mean, when you run it in sqlite3?  not via your server

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: db.execute puts the semicolon in your query automatically, so if you were trying to fix your problem by adding a semicolon, that's not going to help.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: but when you run the query manually (in sqlite3) you have to type it.

Author: WhipStreak23#6131
Content: is it the where?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: ~~the query looks fine to me, so I'm not sure~~.  what if you run `.schema mail`  what do you get?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: The problem is that `to` and `from` are both  reserved keywords in sqlite

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: try putting them into quotes

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `SELECT * FROM mail WHERE "to" = 1 OR "from" = 1;`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: alternatively, and probably better ... change the column names to something other than `to` and `from`

Content: `sqlite3 <database.db>`   (replace with your own db)

Content: like for cs50 finance you'd run `sqlite3 finance.db`

Content: @WhipStreak23

Content: @Mr. Distinguished Depends on what you want to do with it. MS SQL is usually the top pick when you're also using other MS products. Author: L √ñ √ñ P S#7263
Content:
Hello guys!
I've heard that it's recommended to use an unique salt for every password you hash.
Now, what is the best procedure to get that unique salt? Can I just use the username/e-mail as salt?

Author: L √ñ √ñ P S#7263
Content:
Here is the code that I currently use to hash the password:
||
```Python
pbkdf2_hmac('sha256', passw.encode('ascii'), SALT.encode('ascii'), 100000)
```
||
`passw` is the user's password and `SALT` is a constant salt

Author: Maarten#1004
Content: @L √ñ √ñ P S In most cases you can just use the built-in features for randomized salts. For example, the generate_password_hash() function used in the Flask parts of CS50 is doing just that.  If you check the databases there you might see something like this in the users table:

Author: Maarten#1004
Content: If you check out the manual for the function, you'd notice that the stuff between the dollar signs after 50000 is the randomized salt (check that here: https://werkzeug.palletsprojects.com/en/0.15.x/utils/#module-werkzeug.security )

Author: Maarten#1004
Content: No need to reinvent the wheel there (but you could of course give it a go).

Author: Maarten#1004
Content: And in case you want to dig deeper into security, OWASP(.org) has some really good information on that, with lots of 'cheatsheets' on github. For this stuff specificaly: https://github.com/OWASP/CheatSheetSeries/blob/master/cheatsheets/Password_Storage_Cheat_Sheet.md

Author: L √ñ √ñ P S#7263
Content:
Thanks a lot! I'll use `generate_password_hash` and `check_password_hash` and check OWASP after I finish my task.

I still have a question now. If the salt is randomly generated and it's not stored in the database, then how does `check_password_hash` know which salt to use when a password from log in is given to it? The salt used at the registration has to be the same as the salt used at the log in.

Author: Maarten#1004
Content: The salt  and iterations are already known (before and between the 2 $ signs). Those values are stored with the hashed password, so the function can use those values.

Author: L √ñ √ñ P S#7263
Content: Oh yeah, right. I was assuming that I will have to store only the hash in the database. Thanks!

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: @Archdevil  It may be due to the use of a local file to track session?  (`# Configure session to use filesystem (instead of signed cookies)`)

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: Every time Heroku boots (or reboots) your site, it could be on a different machine/virtual machine so session info is lost.  You could look into using cookie sessions instead.

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: Of course, it could  be something else wrong as well.

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: Would you show the SQL statement that is creating your list, 'rows' ?

Author: Archdevil#2094
Content: @Penderrin Hi again, i thought of that possibility as well (using local file) but i dont think it explains why the login info sometimes work and sometimes does not

Author: Archdevil#2094
Content:
```# Query database for username
        db.execute("SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = :username",{'username': request.form.get("username")})
        rows = db.fetchall()

        # Ensure username exists and password is correct
        if len(rows) != 1 or not check_password_hash(rows[0][2], request.form.get("password")):
            return apology("invalid username and/or password", 400)

        # Remember which user has logged in
        session["user_id"] = rows[0][0]
        ```

Author: Mxlt08#0159
Content: Are we allowed to create the project using Django instead of Flask?

Author: Mxlt08#0159
Content: also is it ok to use another IDE?

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: Yes and yes

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: @Dmoj There are GET and POST requests that can be made to a URL

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: Your example `example/form?id=5` is an example of a GET request

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: GET request information is embedded in the URL

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: POST request information is in the actual HTML request, as text (often in JSON format)

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: Using Flask, it is possible access either type of data

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content:
For GET request data:
```
newvarfromGET = request.args.get("foo")
```

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content: For POST request data:

Author: Penderrin#5312
Content:
```
newvarfromPOST = request.form.get("bar")
```

Author: Kwarantine#5325
Content:
Morning,
Trying to deploy a Web App to Heroku and everything works well, except the app doesn't save the Session ID very well (least that is my guess.) The current LOGIN IDs can view a few pages before it forces you to re-LOGIN, but newly created users barely ever get past the index page.

For New Users, my guess is because I'm running SQLite which Heroku advises against, which I'm trying work around by implementing Heroku's suggested PostgreSQL (which I've never worked with before) but that doesn't resolve why I have to keep logging in on users that are already established. Thoughts would be great! (I'm running the same Login Required wrapper and code we used with Finance and it works perfectly fine locally.)

You can view the source code here (link to the Heroku site in the readme): https://github.com/TheKwarantine/BooksNook

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: @saf you are asking about CS50-Mobile  and @yesdefinitely is assuming that because you're posting in the #final-project channel (which deals with the Final Project of CS50x),  your question deals with that class.   For CS50-Mobile, each project you submit is graded manually by a member of the CS50 staff.  You should receive an email within about 2 weeks of submission telling you your grade.  That course does not use cs50.me for grading purposes, so you will not see the course listed there.

Content: you should have received an automated email from the cs50 bot to confirm that your form submission was received.

App... Does not look half as complex as the GTD workflow as I remember it (>10a between reading the book and now). Content: The final project requirements are very open.  Essentially, take what you learned in the class and make something. As long as it requires more effort than (your longest) pset, it should be fine.  Just for reference, in the 'in person' Harvard CS50, the final project counts for 10% of the grade  whereas the psets count for 60%  if that gives you an idea of time spent.

Author: Mr. Distinguished#9941
Content:
Alright question for the more knowledgeable and experienced:
My final project web app is going to handle user inputted sensitive data (full names of clients who's information is protected by HIPPA law).

I therefore need to made sure that all http traffic is secure (so https). How do I do this? Is it as simple as "choose a server host that is https enabled"? Or is it much more complicated?

Thanks!

Author: Maarten#1004
Content: @Mr. Distinguished What I can find (I'm by no means a HIPAA expert, we have different requirements over here) it's not just https enabled and go. HIPAA requires  a couple of things from the certificate, which will rule out some. Best to look for HIPAA complaint hosting I suppose?

Author: Maarten#1004
Content: And from the pricing I see for hipaa complaint hosting, I wouldn't go there unless you have a company willing to invest.

Author: Mr. Distinguished#9941
Content:
@Maarten Ah gotcha. I had implemented several of my own custom safe guards (scrambling names before storage on the disk for example). But I did not even think to look up actually hippa compliant web hosting. I'll research that more. Thanks. 

I do plan on giving the program to a company, but they can always just run the server from their computer, completely separate from the web.

Author: MatMiLam#5890
Content: As I look for whats next, I've seen CS50 web, CS50 beyond and even heard cs51 mentioned. Do you know the difference between them?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: CS50 Web is on edX, and it's a semester long course that expands on what you learned in the last part of CS50x.   CS50 Beyond was an intensive 5-day course that covered just above everything from CS50 Web  (it was run in Jan 2019 so you might consider it the updated version of CS50W)  CS50 Beyond isn't on edX, but you can access the materials here:  https://cs50.harvard.edu/beyond/2019/winter/syllabus/

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: CS51 is Harvard course that is not open-sourced so is not online.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: There is also CS50 Mobile & CS50 Games, which are on edX as well, if those are of interest.  All of the CS50 edX courses are found here: http://edx.org/cs50

Here's some code: ```python

                   email=request.form.get("email"), password=passhash)
```

Content: try running it manually

Content: sqlite 3.22.0

Content: so if you load your db in the terminal  `sqlite3 clubganizer.db`  and then run that insert query with the values you are using, do you see the error?

Content: The exact same query, without any substitutions?

Content: with the values you are trying to insert.

Author: Blex#3615
Content: Ah ok

Author: Blex#3615
Content: I ran that, and nothing happened.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: for example ```INSERT INTO users (email, password) VALUES ("test@test.com", "pass");```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: `SELECT * from users where email = "test@test.com";`

Content: does that then return a row?

Content: Oh ok, let me try that.

Content:
```python
Error: near "email": syntax error
```

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: What does your table look like? Any "UNIQUE" or "NOT NULL" constraints you might miss?

Author: Blex#3615
Content: I have an ID field that's set to NOT NULL but it Auto Increments

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: can you paste (or show screenshot) of the exact command you typed and the error?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: you aren't at a main sqlite prompt

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Could it be that this is the second line of another command?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Oh, or a Python prompt, not `sqlite3` prompt?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: I'd suspect that you ran a prior query but didn't end it in `;`

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: so hitting enter gives you another line

Author: Blex#3615
Content: Yes, that's true

Author: Blex#3615
Content: Should I re-run the query then?

Content: yes, make sure it shows `sqlite>` at the beginning of the line

Author: Blex#3615
Content: It does, I reran it, and it says that the ID NOT NULL constraint is unsatisfied

Author: Blex#3615
Content: I think I know why. I never set a default value for it

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: what does `.schema users` show?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: ok

Author: Blex#3615
Content: Let me try this again with the default value.

Content: Excellent! It works now! Thank you very much for your assistance. üòÑ

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
@Animaster7 I might be able to explain why your multiple `$.get` did not work as expected. `$.get` triggers the GET request, and then continues in the code. The browser in the background performs the request, and when it is done, enqueues your callback function to be run whenever there's time. So your multiple callback functions don't run immediately, and they don't necessarily run in right order. All three callback functions will push to the same `scriptpart`, and will push it to `scriptlines`, that's why you have 3x same array with content of all three files.
You could use callbacks to handle this (e.g. count the open/completed requests and have the last to complete trigger further action), more modern would be to use jQuery's "Deferred"s or the new standard Promise, possibly with async/await. But asynchronous programming is a challenging concept. But it's the only way to handle the limitation that JavaScript only ever runs one code at the same time. Setting the GET request to synchronous (that's possible) would pause the whole page, maybe the window, or the whole browser, until completion.

Author: brunosra#5067
Content:
Hi all, good morning! I've got a question regarding the final project:
Is is ok to use the cs50 python library (for example, the sql part) in the final project? Or it's best to try to use another technology?
I'm new to development and I'm struggling to do my final project because I'm trying to use what I see people calling "more professional frameworks." I've tried to do it with Django and Postgres, but sincerely I'm feeling a little stupid because I struggle even with the setup.

So my new "idea" was to start the final project as Finance, and putting it all down, but using some of the code in it, and doing the project itself. That means I would have to use CS50's library, and Flask, and SQLLite. Is there any problem with that? Thank you in advance.

Author: Nicholas Goldfinder#3350
Content: @brunosra I think the best framework for databases after CS50 is https://www.sqlalchemy.org/

Author: Nicholas Goldfinder#3350
Content: @KubMD it is not in production :). Basically it is automated reporting

Author: brunosra#5067
Content: I think Cs50 uses sqlalchemy. But the question is: is it ‚Äúwrong‚Äù to use the cs50 and SQLite for final project?

Author: Nicholas Goldfinder#3350
Content: @brunosra CS50 uses a its own library, which is not SQLalchemy, but close enough for you to migrate there as a first step out of the CS50 library. AFAIK it is not "wrong" to use the CS50 library, but it is also considered propaedeutic to migrate into a non CS50 context, for the final project. I.e. use another IDE and proper libraries. So, the real answer is "up to you, but I suggest...".

Author: brunosra#5067
Content: Thank you for your answer, @Nicholas Goldfinder . I'm already using VSCode, and setup the dev environment in my local machine. I'm going to try SQLAlchemy and see if I can get those training wheels off! üôÇ

Author: eli1stark#0264
Content: how can I upload image to a database from front-end and then display it in the user's profile?

Author: Boyuan#0628
Content: @eli1stark That's a great question. I would suggest 2 ways to do it: First, which is a bit complicated but more secure way, you would need to create a form in front end, let user be able to submit the file to a directory/folder that you will be working with. In db, only store username and user's profile. Then you will fetch the info for the user. Or, in less security and db memory less concerned way, you can just store the binary info in the db, then read it when needed.

Content: @manu4216 CS50x is essentially open ended.  There is no final deadline for the final project.  The only thing that will probably change with the 2020 course will be the submit50 instruction.

Author: manu4216#3071
Content: I'd like to get a normal non verified certificate

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: If you want to complete the course using the 2019 CS50x course, you have to complete it by 31 December.  But if you don't, your progress carries forward to the 2020 course.  You may have to do any new psets that are part of the 2020 course, but we haven't finalized on that yet.  But there will be a chart on the course's homepage that explains what you need to complete in order to be eligible for a certificate.

Content: I'm working on self-hosting my final project app on a machine inside my local network. One thing that I'm having trouble with is that I'm not sure how to point phpmyadmin to the database file that sits in `/var/www/cs50` I'm still looking for a solution but if anyone can help point me in the right direction that would be lovely

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: Does the final project have to be publically accessible? My thought is that setting up a full server environment from scratch would be part of the project that I showcase but I'm not sure how to show the work behind what I have done. I can submit the code for the app itself but how can I show the work of configuring a web server with a full LAMP stack? I am not going to open my home network to the internet so while I can show video of how it works (once it is working), nobody outside of my network will be able to verify what I have done.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: It doesn't have to be public.  That's why  the only requirement is a video demonstrating it.

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: Cool, I've really been enjoying learning about networking and how to set up my app on it's own box. It's good to know that I can use that as part of the project because I feel like I can aim a little lower with the actually implementation of the app if my setup can be part it. Still haven't figured out how to get the database to open in phpmyadmin... maybe tomorrow.

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: Got it, I was trying to use php**my**admin to open a sqlite database. I needed to be using php**lite**admin.

Author: !.DRAKOLA.!#0101
Content:
hi 
Is it allowed to use external sources like nav bar and footer in building the project?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content:
The final project gives almost no restrictions, just that you still should follow the Academic Honesty guidelines (https://cs50.harvard.edu/x/2020/syllabus/#academic-honesty)
I think including external libraries for such UI tasks is perfectly reasonable, as long as your code is still a major part of the project, and not just a one-liner calling a demo function in the library üòâ

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: I don't know whether you are doing a web project, but those often rely on jQuery and bootstrap libraries. Nothing wrong with that, and as they are separate files, it's also pretty clear they are not the student's code.

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @Homosexual Toaster They will have something like `app.route("/product/<int:product_id>", methods=["GET"])`, maybe not in Python, and they will probably have a cache in front, so relatively static websites, or parts of them, don't have to be regenerated each time. If you pull in stocks via an API, even the "sold out in this version" might be dynamically loaded into the existing quasi-static product website.

Author: Pizdulis#1032
Content:
@Homosexual Toaster Exactly what @Blauelf said. The exact code snippet I used is as follows:
```@app.route("/finance/<finance_id>", methods=["GET", "POST"])
def finance(finance_id):```
The rest you should be able to figure out.

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: Question about SQLite datatypes. Is it possible to store python objects in the database? If more context is needed, let me know.

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: More reading on StackOverflow indicates that it is not possible to do that is a clean way. I'll have to come up with a work around...

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @dexmexter You could store a nested structure of dicts/lists as a JSON string, and parse them again. And there's the object relational model in SQLAlchemy. Do not store pickles, those are not meant for long-term storage.

Author: Sanath#7244
Content: if your data doesnt have much structure, nosql is an option too

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content:
I'm trying to create a sudoku game. I have a class object for each cell. To store a puzzle into my database I figured out a way to convert the puzzle into a string of numbers for storage and then convert it back into the puzzle when I retrieve the string. Now I'm working on how to present the puzzle to a user so that they can make edits and save those edits for later. 

I'm thinking this could be accomplished with a table that is wrapped in a form? Some of the cells can just display numbers but the ones that are editable can be text input. Haven't finished working through it but that is my target at the moment.

Oh, that did work.
```
$ touch expenses.db

Running phpLiteAdmin at https://...
Exit with ctrl-c...
```

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: `touch` is a tool that by default updates the modification date of a file to current, and if the file does not exist, it creates it. In this function, similar to `copy NUL newfile` on MS-DOS/Windows.

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: Hello i have a question

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content:
I have three tables
1) Users (id PRIMARY KEY, name)
2) Category (id PRIMARY KEY, category , user_id FOREIGN KEY from Users)
3) Transaction (id PRIMARY KEY, user_id, category FOREIGN KEY from Category)

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: in SQL

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: I want to insert a row into Transaction

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content:
For example, in a database where the user id 1 exists, and the category named 'test' exists:

INSERT INTO Transaction (user_id, category) VALUES 1, 'test'

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: This is not working for me

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: RuntimeError: foreign key mismatch - "transaction" referencing "category"

Author: Sinergy#7605
Content:
Foreign key has to reference a primary key in another table.  category is not a primary key in Category.  I have seen some indication that the column being UNIQUE is sufficient but W3Schools doesn't back that up explicitly.  You might consider having the foreign key reference Category(id)?  But then again I don't want to tell you to change how your database works.
Also, finally, maybe what you have also valid, but your syntax is not the same as what I'm familiar with in MySQL:
``FOREIGN KEY foreignKeyName REFERENCES otherTable(otherTablesPrimaryKey)``

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: Oh yeah, i was typing from my cellphone so i didn't type the specific syntax with which i created the table, just the main components to give you an idea of how it works

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: Category is referencing User's primary key

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: But i'm still having trouble inserting the data into a foreign key field

Author: Sinergy#7605
Content: as before, category in Category is not your primary key, so category in Transaction can't be a foreign key

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: Ahhhhh

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: I get it

Author: Svnhue#9504
Content: Thank you! Later when i sit to work on the proyect i will try to fix it and report back

Some people take the layout of `finance` and build their own project on that. Or they just use the cs50 SQL wrapper, because it's convenient.

Author: niV#5484
Content: I have the cs50 library working just fine(when I put the flag -lcs50 when interpreting in the terminal), as well as flask, but when I try to combine these two and type in "flask run" on a python file that imports from libcs50, I get "ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'cs50'", probably cause I did not type in the flag. Has anyone ran flask on your machine? How did u do about it?

Author: ziller#6589
Content: if you install cs50 with pip you should be fine

Author: ziller#6589
Content: as long as your flask app is using python 3.6

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: @niV Do not confuse the libcs50 (https://cs50.readthedocs.io/library/c/) with python-cs50 (https://cs50.readthedocs.io/library/python/)

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Different things, even though they are meant to provide a similar interface.

Author: niV#5484
Content: yes, I actually realized that I only downloaded the lib for C and solved that problem, but now I get "ImportError: No module named flask_session", probably due to compatibility issues, as mentioned by @ziller

Author: niV#5484
Content: I have python3.7 installed but the version that is executing is python 2.7, and I have installed flask both through pip and through pip3, but I don't know how to check which version is running. I've searched lots of forums and youtube videos and nothing seemed to work for me. Does anyone know why?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: If `flask run` does not use your python3, maybe you could call flask from the application file instead, and run that with `python3`.

Author: niV#5484
Content: makes sense, thank you

Author: niV#5484
Content: do you happen to know the syntax for that?

Author: Blauelf#6622
Content: Ah, I found another alternative: `python3 -m flask run` would ensure it runs on the Python 3 interpreter.

Author: ziller#6589

Author: niV#5484
Content: For my final project, I'd like to make a web application that shows the difference between C and python. Whenever a C or Python program is put there, it shows the assembly code, the time and memory used. Some additional features could be letting the user store a program in C and another in Python that produce the exact same output from a given input, so other people can see. There could also be an explanation that shows up when you click on an assembly operator about what it does superficially, and some data that says something like "C programs ended up being 13% faster and occupying 10% less memory" scraped from the website. If anyone would like to team up, let me know.

Author: Boyuan#0628
Content: @niV I think why Python is slower than C is because C is much  closer to actual machine code , so it spend much quicker to compile. While for Python, I believe it need to translate Python in to C first, then translate to machine code, which going to spend much more time than C.

Author: esslam#5357
Content: Because python is an interpreted language, and C is a compiled language, this is one of the reasons, there are many other.

Author: esslam#5357
Content: And because it's dynamically typed

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: I found a python library that I wish to incorporate into my project, am I allowed to do so if I clearly link to the original location of the code I wish to use? Would this go against the Academic Honesty Policy?

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: as in something you would put in an import statement?

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content:
Right, it is a set of functions that I am importing into my app.py file for creating and formatting information. It is a single python file but my concern is that since I did not write it, and it is more than just a few lines, using it might invalidate the rest of my project. 

The argument I would like to make in favour of using it is that there are many other libraries (cs50 library and flask) that I am using even though I also did not write those. I hope that it is fine as long as I give proper attribution but I would like to get confirmation before submitting the project. 

If I can't use it, what options do I have? I could rewrite the file by altering the variable names but regardless of how much I change, I am still getting the idea and function structure from someone else.

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: There is no question whether you are allowed to use it

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: As long as you aren‚Äôt claiming it is yours

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: @dexmexter you can use it no question

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: Cool, do you know what the best practice is for giving proper attribution?

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: For stuff in import statements no need

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: Bc it already says the name of the package right there and that‚Äôs all you can provide

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content:
Okay but I could write my own functions in a separate file and import those in the same way.

My plan is to have a references.md file where I link to the original github repo.

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: That‚Äôs perfect

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: What are you thinking about for your final project?

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: I've finished putting it together, I just haven't put the video together for posting. I've made a Sudoku app that generates puzzles and verifies if they have been solved. The puzzles can also be saved in a database and worked on at a later time. There are a few other nice-to-have features that I've included but that it is basic idea.

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: I also chose to setup my own linux virtual server and host the project on my local network. Unfortunately that means I am not able to share a hosted version with everyone b/c I am not wanting to open my home network to the internet.

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: Wow! That sounds amazing

Author: dexmexter#1184
Content: @Sanath  I have a spare computer that I was not using so I have been planning to turn it into a personal server. I installed a project called Proxmox for managing multiple Virtual Machines. I then installed Ubuntu server in a VM and got Apache2 web server running so that I can have an always-on version of my app running and responding to requests. I just have to open a browser and enter the static IP address of the server and then I can play sudoku. My wife can do the same and have her own account with her own puzzles.

Author: AsxzTheApteryx#0097
Content:
Hey everyone! Hope the projects are going OK. I have been on the web dev track, and I'm now working on a language learning app. I have a dictionary in a csv and I'm trying to load the words and their meanings etc. into a database. 

I've stumbled across a problem using sqlite3 in Visual Studio Code. Essentially in Pset8 we had "import cs50" at the top of the application.py file. This allowed us to use keyword arguments when manipulating the database. An example from my finance, application.py is here: 

`# Record a log of the transaction`
            `db.execute("""INSERT INTO history(user_id, symbol_id, stock_change, cash_change)`
                                    `VALUES (:user_id, :symbol, :stock_change, :cash_change)""",`
                                    `user_id=session["user_id"],`
                                    `symbol=lookup(request.form.get("symbol"))["symbol"],`
                                    `stock_change=int(request.form.get("shares")),`
                                    `cash_change=cost)`

In my final project I am trying to INSERT INTO my database, but I keep being told that `.execute() doesn't take keyword arguments`. The keyword arguments e.g. `cash_change=cost` are allowed in the pset8 finance project because we import cs50 at the top I want to be able to code in Visual Studio Code with sqlite3 (as I'll continue doing this after the course) and I don't want to rely on the cs50 library. 

I've tried *so many* different ways of formatting it in my Visual Studio Code file, but every time I run it, the `print(counter, word)` line works, but the table returns no data when I `SELECT * FROM words;` 

Does anyone here have insight on how to take off the CS50 training wheels and make this INSERT INTO command work? Happy to share more of my code if that helps.

        word = row["WORD"]
        type = row["TYPE"]
        db.execute("INSERT INTO words(dict_key, dict_version, word, type) VALUES(?,?,?,?)", (key, version, word, type))

        print(counter, word)```

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: are you doing the commit step?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
```python
c = conn.cursor()

# Create table
c.execute('''CREATE TABLE stocks
             (date text, trans text, symbol text, qty real, price real)''')

# Insert a row of data
c.execute("INSERT INTO stocks VALUES ('2006-01-05','BUY','RHAT',100,35.14)")

# Save (commit) the changes
conn.commit()

# We can also close the connection if we are done with it.
# Just be sure any changes have been committed or they will be lost.
conn.close()```

conn = sqlite3.connect("small_dict.db")

filename = "small.csv"

with open(filename, "rt", encoding="utf-8-sig") as file:
    reader = csv.DictReader(file)
    counter = 0
    # Skip over header row and store info in a variable headers
    for row in reader:
        # Store dict_key, dict_version, word and type in words
        counter += 1
        key = int(row["KEY"])
        version = int(row["VERSION"])
        word = row["WORD"]
        type = row["TYPE"]
        db.execute("INSERT INTO words(dict_key, dict_version, word, type) VALUES(:dk,:dv,:w,:t)", {"dk":key, "dv":version, "w":word, "t":type})

        print(counter, word)

conn.commit

Author: L.S.#6002
Content: Hi everyone, I'm having a very annoying problem with my project, and I'm not sure if the problem lies on my side or if it has something to do with the IDE. For my final project I'm building a website using Flask, but the project has gotten rather large and messy, so I want to divide it up into smaller files stored inside a Python package. The problem is, every time I try to run the website, I can't even get past the first step, which is to import `app` from my package. Python is simply not reading it. I've even created a new project solely for testing purposes and it's the same thing.

Author: L.S.#6002
Content:
For my testing project, I have this set up:
```
project/
   | package/
   |   | __init__.py
   |   | routes.py
   | application.py```

Author: L.S.#6002
Content:
In `application.py`, there's only this:
```python
from package import app
if __name__ == '__main__':
    app.run()```
And in `__init__.py`, there's this:
```python
from flask import Flask
app = Flask(__name__)
from package import routes```
And finally, in `routes.py`, there's just this:
```python
from package import app
@app.route("/")
def home():
    return "Homepage placeholder"```

But this is the error I get when I try to load the website:
```Error on request:

ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'package'

  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/cli.py", line 326, in _flush_bg_loading_exception
    reraise(*exc_info)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/_compat.py", line 39, in reraise
    raise value
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/cli.py", line 314, in _load_app
    self._load_unlocked()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/cli.py", line 330, in _load_unlocked
    self._app = rv = self.loader()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/cli.py", line 388, in load_app

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: About how many hours should it take to make the final project?

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: honestly, however many hours it takes for you to be proud of the final product and proud of the work you put in

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: how long have you spent on it so far?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content:
> About how many hours should it take to make the final project?
@psychodoughb0y per the spec: 
> A one-person project should entail more time and effort than is required by each of the course‚Äôs problem sets.
ie, if you spent 15 hours on the longest problem set, then your final project should entail more hours than that.  It's up to you how much time you want to spend beyond that.

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: I missed that, thanks.  So Tideman took me about 6 hours, so this taking around 20 hours might be enough then?

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: well, problem set not individual problem (ie, the complete week's worth of work), but yes, 20 hours seems reasonable in your case.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: It's all about the learning anyway, so there's no set amount that is required.

Author: curiouskiwi#1671
Content: We leave that to you.

Author: psychodoughb0y#0892
Content: That makes sense.

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: np

Author: Zeina#6519
Content: why did it have to be ``name[0]['username']``

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: because db.execute() returns a list of dictionaries

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: with each index of the list representing a row, the keys of the dicts being the column names, and the values being the values

Author: GhostDragon#7128
Content: `[{'username': 'ricardo'}]` as you can see here, there are both square brackets, for lists, and curly brackets, for dicts

Author: Louky#3520
Content:
Heyy!! Are there any Dutch people here who want to collaborate on the final project, making a webapplication. 
Yesterday since the announcement was made that restaurants and terraces can open soon, but reservations and control conversations are obligatory, I had the idea to make a central website that could manage both. 
This website would need to have the following functionalities:
- A register and login for both restaurant-owners and customers
- A page where restaurant owners can add info, a link to their own site, and max number of customers
- A general page where customers can look through all the available terraces, with a counter for the amount of reservations already made, with max 30. 
- A page where customers can make a reservation, and before being able to do so. a  page where they have to make an online statement, questionnaire about not having had any symptoms  
- A database in sql that keeps track of reservations and restaurants 
The main use of the website would be that it could help to distribute customers evenly by the way it orders the restaurants on the main page, and there could be a central form for a control conversation (approved by regulators) so that restaurant owners don't have to do that themselves. 
I would like to use JavaScript, HTML and CSS and find someone who has affinity with design in CSS and someone who is capable of managing databases in SQL.  Do reach out to me if you would like to collaborate.
